medical_history.chief_complaint: Right-sided neck pain, hoarseness, and dysphagia.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient had been well until 7 days ago when sudden pain developed in his right mandible and teeth while performing manual labor. Minutes later, he experienced bilateral blurred vision and unsteadiness, which resolved after 10 to 15 minutes. The jaw pain lasted for 3 hours before resolving. Several hours later, pain in the right posterior neck and right-sided headache developed, rated at 8 out of 10, without nausea or vomiting. After taking NSAIDs, the headache improved but neck pain persisted. Two days later, hoarseness and swelling of the tongue developed, along with dysphagia for solid foods.
medical_history.past_medical_history: The patient had borderline hypertension and a history of 35 fractures attributed to osteogenesis imperfecta.
medical_history.family_history: His father had hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and numerous fractures. His mother was healthy, and his grandmother and great-aunt had fractures.
medical_history.social_history: The patient works in construction, involving frequent heavy lifting. He is married, lives with his wife and son, drinks alcohol in moderation, does not smoke, and does not use illicit drugs.
